title: Interest Limitation Rules - Inland Revenue NZ
description:
Do you own rental property in New Zealand? If so, the interest limitation rules may apply to you. Residential rental properties are subject to the interest limitation rules unless an exclusion or exemption applies.  

For residential rental property acquired before 27 March 2021, the ability to claim mortgage interest as an expense is being phased out between 1 October 2021 and 31 March 2025. 

For residential rental property acquired on or after 27 March 2021, no mortgage interest can be claimed from 1 October 2021.  

You can find out more here: www.ird.govt.nz/property-interest-rules

title: Received an income tax bill? | End of Tax Year
description:
Tax is vital to New Zealand life, but it can be complicated. Wondering why you've got an income tax bill? There are reasons why this could happen. Like a change in income or being on the wrong tax code. Everyone's situation is different. 

Find out more: https://www.ird.govt.nz/end-of-tax-year

----------------------------------------------------------------

More information:

The tax year is from 1 April to 31 March. After the end of the tax year, we work out if you’ve paid the right amount of tax, if you have tax to pay, or if you're due a refund.

Find out more about what happens at the end of the tax year: https://www.ird.govt.nz/income-tax/income-tax-for-individuals/what-happens-at-the-end-of-the-tax-year

If your income is already taxed before you get it, you can expect to hear from us by early June. If you have other types of income and need to file an income tax return (IR3), you can do this from early April until 7 July. Find out more about timelines at the end of the tax year: https://www.ird.govt.nz/income-tax/income-tax-for-individuals/what-happens-at-the-end-of-the-tax-year/timelines-at-the-end-of-the-tax-year

title: Business Basics | Registering for GST
description:
Starting your own business can be pretty exciting. Being your own boss, working on the projects you want to, and being responsible for your own tax matters. In this series, we cover some of the key topics you need to know before getting into business. Goods and Services Tax, also known as GST, is a tax added to the sales price of most goods and services sold here in New Zealand. You'll need to register for GST if your sales for the last 12 months were more than $60,000 or if you expect your sales for the next 12 months to be more than $60,000. Find out more: https://www.ird.govt.nz/gst/registering-for-gst

----------------------------------------------------------------

More information:

Businesses, organisations, non-profits and charities have certain tax obligations when setting up. They may also have obligations with other government agencies like the Companies Office or Charities Services. Find out more: https://www.ird.govt.nz/setting-up-a-business-or-organisation

Find out more about if you need to register for GST: https://www.ird.govt.nz/gst/registering-for-gst

If you're registered for GST, you'll need to charge GST at 15% on most taxable supplies you make. This means you pay 15% of the price you charge for your goods and services to us. Find out more about when and not to charge GST: https://www.ird.govt.nz/gst/charging-gst

You're likely to be charged GST on most supplies you purchase for your taxable activity. The amount of GST you claim (input tax) is subtracted from the amount of GST you charge (output tax) to calculate your tax to pay or GST refund. Find out more about what can be claimed: https://www.ird.govt.nz/gst/claiming-gst

If you liked this video, why not watch more of our Business Basics series: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RdjH34_TFbE&list=PLEOLlaTZfeti2efaNfgEcara1F8S7XLxC&pp=gAQBiAQB

description:

You can sign up to use AIM any time during the year.
